RECORDS.title: Nicotiana Rustica Seeds (Aztec Tobacco)
RECORDS.text:
Ornamental use only - not for consumption. Plant responsibly. 

Nicotiana rustica, known in South America as Mapacho, is a plant in the Solanaceae family. It is a very potent variety of tobacco. The high concentration of nicotine in its leaves makes it useful for creating organic pesticides. 

Rustica is also used for entheogenic purposes by South American shamans. Growing in the rainforest it contains up to twenty times more nicotine than common North American varieties such as N. tabacum. Other reasons for its shamanic use are the comparatively high levels of MAOI beta-carbolines, including harman and norharman. 

Nicotiana Rustica has an extremely high nicotine content. The nicotine content can reach as high as 9% giving it some use as a natural organic pesticide. It produces millions of seeds, hundreds of small yellow to greenish flowers, and grows to about four feet tall. This is related to smoking tobacco, and has been used for the same purpose in the past.

RECORDS.title: Nicotiana Sylvestris Seeds
RECORDS.text:
Nicotiana sylvestris is a species of wild tobacco known by the common names Woodland Tobacco and South American Tobacco. It is native to South America, and is often grown in gardens for its scented flowers. The scent is strongest at night, so as to attract pollinating moths. The leaves are simple, somewhat sticky, foul-smelling, with the blade partially surrounding the stem (clasping petiole). Flowers are tubular, white, borne in large clusters above the foliage. Flowers can be over 7 centimeters long with a face 2 centimeters wide. Each flower eventually produces a large quantity of small seeds.


1000 Viable Nicotiana Sylvestris Seeds per packet Nicotiana sylvestris is a species of wild tobacco known by the common names Woodland Tobacco and South American Tobacco. It is native to South America, and is often grown in gardens for its scented flowers. The scent is strongest at night, so as to attract pollinating moths. The leaves are simple, somewhat sticky, foul-smelling, with the blade partially surrounding the stem (clasping petiole). Flowers are tubular, white, borne in large clusters above the foliage. Flowers can be over 7 centimeters long with a face 2 centimeters wide. Each flower eventually produces a large quantity of small seeds. This plant is thought to be one of the parents of Nicotiana tobacum, the plant used in modern tobacco production.

RECORDS.title: Verbascum thapsus (Great or Common Mullein) Seeds
RECORDS.text:
A packet of 1000 seeds. 
Great Mullein has been used since ancient times as a remedy for skin, throat and breathing ailments. It has long had a medicinal reputation, especially as an astringent and emollient, as it contains mucilage, several saponins, coumarin and glycosides. Dioscorides recommended it for diseases of the lung and it is now widely available in health and herbal stores. Non-medical uses have included dyeing and making torches. 
The plant's leaves, in addition to the seeds, have been reported to contain rotenone, although quantities are unknown 
This plant is a hairy biennial plant that can grow to 2 m or more tall. Its small yellow flowers are densely grouped on a tall stem, which bolts from a large rosette of leaves. It grows in a wide variety of habitats, but prefers well-lit disturbed soils, where it can appear soon after the ground receives light, from long-lived seeds that persist in the soil seed bank. It is a common weedy plant that spreads by prolifically producing seeds, but rarely becomes aggressively invasive, since its seed require open ground to germinate.

RECORDS.title: Villages Quick Guide
RECORDS.text:
villages > help

This is a brief guide to Villages and its terminology. 
[Work in Progress. Please send suggestions.]

Villages is an online economic system with:
- a social network of producers
- a marketplace of ads and private messages
- a payment system (credit clearing)
- an alternative currency (mutual credit)

It is based on the Ripple web-based mutual credit clearing system. Ripple models how people actually extend each other varying amounts of credit based on experience and trust. Then it finds paths of trust to enable strangers to pay each other. So unlike LETS, there is no collectivized debt exposure requiring arbitrary administration.

GLOSSARY  
Post - ad or announcement
Hour - unit and name of currency (time-based, divided with decimals)

Endorse - to extend a line of credit
Heart - hour-unit of line of credit

Acknowledge - to credit or pay 
Trusted - endorsed
Direct - unendorsed

Health - a person's unused percentage of your endorsement. A simple credit rating.
Overall Balance - total hours
Trusted Balance - trusted hours
Reputation - total hearts with you, both directly and indirectly through a person's trusted paths to you in the network.

When posting, use "Easy Categories". See next post or:
https://villages.cc/posts/148/

RECORDS.title: Seeking input on new direction for Villages
RECORDS.text:
A couple days ago, I watched a video of Alfie Kohn talking about how when you give students grades, they lose motivation for true learning.  Here's a small part:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EQt-ZI58wpw

It occurred to me that the same might be said of money:  When people work for money, they lose motivation for true giving.  

Maybe we should simplify Villages by getting rid of the monetary aspect entirely.  No hours, no hearts, just one way to indicate that you think someone's OK, no number attached.  Then we can find good people to help and help us out, and not worry about the numbers -- that was never the point anyway.  And if we happen to help someone out who never gives back, oh well, it's only helping them to come around eventually.  If people want to transact in cash, that's fine too, but ideally it would be by donation...

So...  What do you lovely people think?  Reply to this post, or in the discussion group I've set up:

https://groups.google.com/group/villagescc/

Thanks!

Ryan

RECORDS.title: Evaluate IOPS
RECORDS.text:
Evaluate the (interim) International Organization for a Participatory Society.

I'm willing to acknowledge your efforts at a rate of 1 Village Hour to 1 hour of evaluation. Let me know how much you are going to do and we will shake on the deal.

Tasks:

1. Evaluate the IOPS vision and write a paragraph describing your views on it:

    http://www.iopsociety.org/vision

2. If you agree with the IOPS vision, evaluate the IOPS structure and program and write a paragraph describing your views on it:

    http://www.iopsociety.org/structure-and-program

3. If you agree with the IOPS vision, structure and program, write a paragraph describing your reasons for either joining or not joining IOPS.

I'll want to publish what you write.  I'd appreciate if you have a blog, if you would publish it there as well.  If you aren't comfortable writing, I'd be happy if you record verbal explanations instead.  I would prefer if any writing you do is in your own voice, language and dialect or accent.  I'm not interested in "grammar" and punctuation.

RECORDS.title: Game or Fiction Reading Reviews
RECORDS.text:
I am offering my services as a reader for game or fiction texts. 

For game texts: I am a very critical reader and I am very good at finding areas in rules text where the rule seems ambiguous, or where there may be unusual side-effects.

For fiction: I can nitpick down to syntax and grammar pretty well, but I am not a professional editor. I am good at picking apart confusing dialogue or descriptions, and I'm good at noticing when loose ends aren't all tied up by the end.

Contact me and we'll talk about your specific needs.

RECORDS.title: Game Design Consulting
RECORDS.text: Many times when people get stuck in the game design process, it's because they've lost that initial burst of energy and excitement. Sometimes they know what the next steps are, but can't quite manage to get them done or find the drive they originally had. In such circumstances, I've had remarkably good luck with having in-depth conversations with designers about their project, their design goals, what "success" would feel like, their publication plans, cutting away the stuff that isn't working, and overall just helping people get back on track and rekindling some excitement about the project.

RECORDS.title: Sci Fi artwork needed for RPG.
RECORDS.text:
I'm looking for 5-10 pieces of sci-fi artwork to illustrate a 2nd print edition of the brilliant storygame While the World Ends.

The game is about ordinary people in a strange future, and what happens in their lives as the world changes around them.

I don't mind reusing art that has been published before in other contexts or even games, as long as I can get rights to use them in mine. I'm not in a real hurry, I'll need it before December, but of course earlier would be better. I'll take B/W or color, sketches, oil paintings, photo manipulations, pixel art or just about anything else.

I need pictures of people doing future stuff: like talking to aliens, working strange machinery, exploring alien worlds, carousing with robots, gazing at the stars while standing on a levitating platform, getting cybernetic implants in their brains, being chased by augmented chimps, guarding disintegrating androids praying with Tibetan monks   Stuff like that, things that happen in the future.

However, I'm not looking for pictures of people posing with future weapons.  While there is conflict in the game, armed conflict is rare. I've never had any PCs who spent time posing.

RECORDS.title: Look at 110,000 Words of Lurid Sorcery (with minor mention of swords)
RECORDS.text:
I have this... thing... that's been accumulating words the same way the cat box accumulates a nasty crust on the bottom.  The few people I've handed it off too have nodded and said "Wow, Gary, it's great!"  Hmm.  Bullhocky sez I.  So I'm looking for someone to tell me what's wrong with it - where (or even if) it can be improved, what I can do better, what parts of the forest I'm missing for being nose-planted against a tree.

I'll provide a PDF with line numbers, double-spaced, in whatever typeface and size you like.  I'll also provide you with this warning: it's (an as yet incomplete) first-person account of someone learning necromancy, and there is violence.  Several persons are flagrantly murdered in the course of the story thus far.  There is even some sexin'!  If you can trudge your way through a GRRM series, I can't imagine my story is much worse.

All I ask in return is a page, maybe, of honest commentary.  Even if that honest commentary is "unfit for fishwrap."

Thanks!

Edited to add: Commentary's coming back and I will shortly be deep in acknowledgement debt - so I'm suspending this want until I get some art out and balance things.  If I've emailed you a document, you'll be acknowledged.

RECORDS.title: Looking for reviews and/or playtests of my game
RECORDS.text:
EDIT: Thanks, all! I'm going to close this down, for now. If you've already set up a playtest, that's great, and I'll definitely still pay you for a report. But otherwise, I'm going to consider this version deprecated, and start writing the next version! :)

~~~

I have a game in development called "Far Horizons of the Unknown". (For those of you who read my Game Chef 2012 runner-up, this is its evolved form.) The one-sentence pitch: One of you will play a competent and interesting hero, while the rest of you build the mysterious and overwhelming world that hero is faced with. It's playable in 2 to 4 hours, with 3-5 players.

I've had some successful preliminary playtests, but I'd love some more feedback. 

I'm offering one hour in return for reading it and giving me your thoughts, or four hours for _playing_ it and giving me your thoughts. (If you record it as well, I'll give you six hours instead. If any of your other players are on Villages, they get two hours for playing, and another two if they also give me their thoughts.) You can feel free to either post comments somewhere online and send me the link, or else just send them directly to me, either way.

There are actually two playsets currently released. For my purposes, either one counts as "the game". You definitely don't have to read/play both of them.

The first is called "The Shadows of the Trees", and is set in a pretty standard sword-and-sorcery world:

http://semielgames.wordpress.com/2012/07/06/the-shadows-of-the-trees-playtest-document/

The second is called "The Coyotes of Chicago", and is about mysterious things happening to urban coyote researchers in Chicago:

http://semielgames.wordpress.com/2012/07/25/the-coyotes-of-chicago-playtest-document/

Drama points are then used to fuel casting spells and in order to cast spells you must speak Korean.

I'm looking for anyone that is willing to give it a read-through, any thoughts on it earns you an hour.

Anyone who is willing to take a look at the Korean system to see if there are any spells that may not be properly represented in the book gets you two hours.

RECORDS.title: Usability test some solo procedures from my roleplaying game
RECORDS.text:
I need some people to try out the adventure-creation procedures in the tabletop roleplaying game I'm designing, Getting There in Time.
http://www.danmaruschak.com/blog/2012/08/07/getting-there-in-time-rev-0-3-2/

The procedures are on pages 8-10 of the PDF available at the link. What I need is for people to try to do the procedure, show me their results, and report on their impressions during the process (e.g. what was difficult or confusing, what was fun, what took a long time, what you enjoyed, what you disliked, etc.), so I can see what is or isn't working the way I want it to in this part of the game. The task is sort of similar to town creation in Dogs in the Vineyard or mission creation in Mouse Guard, but maybe a bit more formalized. You shouldn't need any knowledge of the inspirational source material or knowledge of the other game procedures to do this, although it won't hurt if you have those.

I don't have enough data to know exactly how long it takes, but I suspect it's in the 1 to 2 hour range.

RECORDS.title: MOVEMBER
RECORDS.text:
I am looking for 1 or 2 hour donations sponsorship for my effort to support Male health awareness. 

I am fundraising for http://ca.movember.com/about/ It is a month long race to grow the best moustache and raise awareness for Men's Health. 

Follow my progress at http://mobro.co/darinmbicknell. I will post in mospace if you donate through Villages. I will be working to promote Men's Health at every opportunity and I will get myself an appointment for a Men's Health Checkup as part of the spirit of Movember and as I am getting longer in the tooth it is time to get checked every year. 

So any and all donations are welcome. 1 hour would be nice if I make it the whole the month without going nuts and shaving off the stache... and 2 hours if I also get my check up done in November.  http://ca.movember.com/mens-health/ .

OVERVIEW OF MOVEMBER

During November each year, Movember is responsible for the sprouting of moustaches on thousands of men’s faces, in Canada and around the world. With their “Mo’s”, these men raise vital funds and awareness for men's health, specifically prostate cancer and male mental health initiatives.

On Movember 1st, guys register at Movember.com with a clean-shaven face. For the rest of the month, these selfless and generous men, known as Mo Bros, groom, trim and wax their way into the annals of fine moustachery. Supported by the women in their lives, Mo Sistas, Movember Mo Bros raise funds by seeking out sponsorship for their Mo-growing efforts.

Mo Bros effectively become walking, talking billboards for the 30 days of November. Through their actions and words, they raise awareness by prompting private and public conversation around the often ignored issue of men’s health.

At the end of the month, Mo Bros and Mo Sistas celebrate their gallantry and valor by either throwing their own Movember party or attending one of the infamous Gala Partés held around the world by Movember, for Movember.  

Movember - a global movement

Since its humble beginnings in Melbourne Australia, Movember has grown to become a truly global movement inspiring more than 1.9 Million Mo Bros and Mo Sistas to participate with formal campaigns in Australia, New Zealand, the US, Canada, the UK, South Africa, Ireland, Finland, the Netherlands, Spain, Denmark, Norway, Belgium and the Czech Republic. In addition, Movember is aware of Mo Bros and Mo Sistas supporting the campaign and men’s health cause across the globe, from Russia to Dubai, Hong Kong to Antarctica, Rio de Janeiro to Mumbai, and everywhere in between.

No matter the country or city, Movember will continue to work to change established habits and attitudes men have about their health, to educate men about the health risks they face, and to act on that knowledge, thereby increasing the chances of early detection, diagnosis and effective treatment.

In 2011, over 854,000 Mo Bros and Mo Sistas around the world got on board, raising $125.7 million CAD.

RECORDS.title: Leo Tolstoy wrote
RECORDS.text:
I ask and want nothing today, other than to share a quote that this network reminded me of: 

“Good consists not in the giving of money, it consists in the loving intercourse of men. This alone is needed. Whatever may be the outcome of this, any thing will be better than the present state of things. Then let the final act of our enumerators and directors be to distribute a hundred twenty-kopek pieces to those who have no food; and this will be not a little, not so much because the hungry will have food, because the directors and enumerators will conduct themselves in a humane manner towards a hundred poor people. How are we to compute the possible results which will accrue to the balance of public morality from the fact that, instead of the sentiments of irritation, anger, and envy which we arouse by reckoning the hungry, we shall awaken in a hundred instances a sentiment of good, which will be communicated to a second and a third, and an endless wave which will thus be set in motion and flow between men? And this is a great deal.”

RECORDS.title: Can't figure out PGP? I'll communicate for you
RECORDS.text:
If PGP/encryption is just too hard for you to figure out or something, send me what you want to send, and who you want to send to and I'll send it to someone else using their public key. 

WARNING: I will have the message in plaintext.  Send it to me in person or via snailmail or something.

RECORDS.title: Seeking Radio Talent
RECORDS.text:
Aloha! LavaZoneone Radiohhhh is revving back up!   Need to start with a council of volunteers (to start) to make it happen!  The structure has already been crystallized into being. ᏔᎧ had over 170 countries listening in and the number of listeners in those countries were growing.  The platform is an amazing opp to get things flowing into our community from outside sources, unite community and fund community projects as 90 percent of all
donations goes back to community chosen projects.    It's going to take those who wish to DJ (from home?), those who want to cover personal interest pieces, those who love to crunch numbers,  writers, developers, etc.  ᏔᎧ had great success but the FCC shut the server down leaving 5000 radio broadcasts and 100 million listeners without their favorite live broadcasts.  Anyone interested please connect.

RECORDS.title: Set the Course for the new Year!
RECORDS.text:
In this session we connect to your highest self and receive guidance and answers as to where you ideally are headed for this new year and what"s important for you at this stage. 

You can use this session as a general guidance or move further into healing patterns that hinder you to be your best self. 

Im looking forward to exploring your true potential with you! 

We can chat via Skype or phone to make it easy and comfortable. Just contact me and we create the best start for 2017 for you together!

RECORDS.title: Help with kalo beds
RECORDS.text:
Aloha puna community! I'm located in fern forest and need some help weeding and clearing my neglected kalo beds that I haven't been able to get too close to because they are near my bee hives and unfortunately recently have been allergic to bee stings. Shouldn't be more than few hours work and I'm happy to provide a snack, drinks, and raw honey to take home! Mahalos!

Ps. I should mention the bees are not likely to sting and are generally friendly, just not a risk those with allergy should take of course :)

RECORDS.title: Debian Developer
RECORDS.text:
I would like to help support the development of Debian.  If you're a DD(debian developer) you've probably got stuff you'd *like* to do but since it's all volunteer work sometimes you've got to make bread by doing other things.  Well here's a chance to do debian-related things instead.

There's work that I want done but the important thing is that the work that *you* feel is important gets done, that the administrivia of Debian gets done, that debian continues to hum as a project.
